Award.AwardTitle: The Effect of Geographic Locale on Work-Related Experiential Learning Opportunities
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project examines how students’ work-related experiential activities (WREAs) may be affected by their institution’s geographic proximity to major economic and workforce hubs. WREAs include internships, co-ops, practicums, job shadowing, and other similar opportunities that enable students to apply knowledge in an authentic setting and that lead to successful and productive employment. The research will fill a knowledge gap by empirically documenting the influence of locale on internships and similar professional development opportunities for students. The research is guided by proximity research, constructs implicit in critical human geography that can be examined through dimensions of socio-spatial relations, and the notion of opportunity structures, defined as the full range of opportunities available to students that organize their education and future trajectories. The study will offer thoughtful insight into the employability discourse and demonstrate the importance of the contextual nuance of geographic locale. The study is expected to produce information about the impact of geographic locale on professional development opportunities for students and help strengthen the STEM pipeline from education to the workforce, particularly for students who may be less connected to major workforce hubs.

Guided by proximity research, the researchers will employ a mixed methods design to answer the following research questions: (1) How and to what extent does geographic locale affect STEM students’ access to work-related experimental activities? (2) Do students, university career officials, and/or new employees perceive access to or benefit from WREAs differently based on their institution’s geographic locale? (3) Are there other facets of structural opportunities that intersect with locale that further affect students’ access to or perceptions of WREAs? (4) Does WREA participation affect time to degree and/or time between degree completion and job offer? (5) For recent graduates, who have not secured employment, does their locale contribute to the reason for unemployment, and was their participation in WREAs different from that of peers who have acquired employment? And (6) Do employees who participate in WREAs receive higher salary offers than peers who do not participate in WREAs? Survey data will be collected in multiple phases from enrolled students, employers, and recently hired alumni employees who recruit from five public universities in Georgia, and geospatial analyses will visually situate students in the study, institutions, and WREA locations. Geospatial analyses will consider factors such as physical and functional distances to workplaces and overall amenities. Analysis of qualitative data will provide nuanced information about specific WREA activities as perceived by employers and recently hired employees, while quantitative analysis will provide students’ attitudes and behaviors that show connections between WREA activities and student success. The study will provide a better understanding of the experiential activities that best position students for employment. The findings can inform effective matching between students and subsequent employment and enable employers to quantify their return on investment.

The project is funded by the Directorate for Education and Human Resources Core Research (ECR)program that supports fundamental research that focuses on STEM learning and learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM professional workforce development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Work-related experiential activities (WREAs) provide significant benefits to students, and universities increasingly mandate these types of learning experiences as a graduation requirement (e.g., Hora et al. 2020). Although we know that WREA activities benefit student learning and post-graduation employment, not all students have equal access to the same types or number of postsecondary opportunities. Despite efforts to increase equity, a number of barriers (including social, educational, and economic) still exist by geographic location, and these obstacles may contribute to reproducing inequality of opportunities and outcomes.

Informed by proximity research (e.g., Hillman, 2016; Turley, 2006, 2009; Weis et al., 2015), this study added to the relatively small amount of literature available on the impact of geographic location and access to work-related experiences for engineering and computer science students. Better information on geographic locale will enable students to navigate the path from college to employment, particularly for institutions that may be less connected to major workforce hubs. Because issues of geographic location are entwined with notions of cultural capital (Bourdieu, 1986), underrepresented students, including women, some minorities, and those from lower socioeconomic backgrounds, are especially affected. Better understanding if and how locale enhances employee and employer success will, ultimately, contribute to workplace success and national economic strength.

This mixed-methods study captured survey data from junior and senior-level baccalaureate students as well as rich, nuanced qualitative data via individual interviews with students and institutional Career Center officials at six universities and focus groups with employers. Additional geospatial analyses and visualizations enhanced the interpretation of survey and qualitative data. Individual and focus group data from a total of 97 individuals provided rich, nuanced information that more deeply illuminated survey findings. Individual interviews with Career Center Directors occurred in fall 2021, focus group interviews with employers occurred in summer and fall 2021, and individual interviews were conducted with students across six institutions in spring, summer, and fall 2021.

Along with many email and telephone communications throughout the study period, videoconferences with members of the project's Advisory Committee were held on five dates (September 2021, March 2022, October 2022, April 2023, July 2023). Discussions at each videoconference provided updates on the study's progress and allowed committee members to offer suggestions that helped refine survey or interview questions or otherwise provided clarity to researchers on the process for experiential activity engagement at a specific institution.

Survey results with students at five universities in Georgia revealed that students perceived value in WREA activities. A little over 60% of respondents said they participated in at least one WREA and 60% said they participated in two or more WREAs. Although a few differences were noted, surprisingly few differences were found in perceived impact of WREAs by students' gender, race, and financial aid status. Qualitative findings paralleled survey findings; WREAs were an important way to increase career readiness and offered students the opportunity to connect classroom-based learning and skill development.

Importantly, we found that students, Career Center directors, and employers in our study said that geographic location was significant in determining students' access to WREA opportunities. Students who attended large, highly-resourced institutions located in the major metropolitan areas benefited from greater knowledge about and access to WREAs compared to students who attended less well-resourced institutions in more rural locations. 

Figure 1 shows the locations of WREA activities for survey respondents. As shown, WREA activities occurred across the country to a degree, but were clustered in or near Georgia and near metropolitan areas. The majority of WREAs in Georgia were completed in or near Atlanta, although students enrolled at rural locations were more likely to participate in WREAs closer to their institution. 

Qualitative data not only revealed significant inequality in access to WREAs, generally, but also inequality in the type of WREAs available to students who attended institutions located in different geographic locales. For example, students who attended institutions located in major industry hubs were better able to access WREAs because they were closer in proximity, and their institutions seemed to have stronger networks that enabled more and (as students expressed) 'better' opportunities that positioned them for different outcomes (e.g., positions with 'big-name' companies immediately upon graduation). This finding is significant relative to our larger research question regarding inequality of geographic opportunity, particularly for students situated in rural institutions located outside of larger metro areas.

Our study gathered data during the COVID-19 pandemic which may have contributed to some results. For example, students and employers preferred in-person WREAs, but Career Center directors believe that remote and hybrid WREAs are most likely to continue. This finding, in particular, prompts higher education officials to work closely with employers to design WREAs in ways that continue to enable students to develop professional networks, obtain work-based mentors, and further strengthen skills that will lead to successful career and lifetime employment.
